summary.title: What Happened?
summary.description: Your network has detected DNS (Domain Name System) resolution errors. This means that your device is having trouble translating domain names (Ex: www.example.com) into IP addresses, which can prevent you from accessing websites and online services.

recommendations.text: Unplug your router, wait for 5 seconds, and plug it back in. This can often resolve DNS issues.
Revert any WAN settings changes if acplicable.
If the problem persists, consider performing a factory reset on your router. Note that this will erase all settings, so you will need to reconfigure your network.

summary.title: What Happened?
summary.description: Your broadband connection has been experiencing high latency, which can negatively impact interactive applications such as VoIP (Voice over Internet Protocol) or online gaming. High latency means there is a delay in data transmission, causing lag and poor performance.

recommendations.text: Sometimes, a simple reboot can resolve latency issues. Unplug your router, wait for 5 seconds, and plug it back in.
Ensure all cables are securely connected and there are no visible damages. You shall reduce the number of coaxial splitters to your equipment.

You may have device consuming a lot of CPU resource. You may want to reduce the number of devices connected to your router or close unnecessary applications or services that might be using a lot of bandwidth and CPU resources (Exam
Place your router in a central location, away from walls and other obstructions.
If you notice an improvement after pausing certain devices, you may want to consider upgrading your internet plan.

summary.title: What Happened?
summary.description: Your gateway/router has detected high CPU load recently. This can lead to slow performance, connectivity issues, and potential overheating.

recommendations.text: Unplug your equipment, wait for 5 seconds, and plug it back in. This can help reset the CPU usage.

You may have device consuming a lot of CPU resource. You may want to reduce the number of devices connected to your router or close unnecessary applications or services that might be using a lot of bandwidth and CPU resources (Example: Torrent, ...).
If your equipement is old or frequently runs into high CPU load issues, consider upgrading to a newer model with a more powerful CPU and capabilities.

summary.title: What Happened?
summary.description: Your gateway/router has detected low-memory issues recently. This can lead to slow performance, frequent reboots, and connectivity problems.

recommendations.text: Unplug your equipment, wait for 5 seconds, and plug it back in. This can free up memory and improve performance.

You may have device consuming a lot of CPU resource. You may want to reduce the number of devices connected to your router or close unnecessary applications or services that might be using a lot of bandwidth and CPU resources (Exam
If your equipment is old or frequently runs into memory issues, consider upgrading to a newer model with more memory.

summary.description: Your router has rebooted multiple times recently.

AP_PWR_1.conclusion: If the issue persists, please contact your Internet Service Provider (ISP) or the router manufacturer forfurther assistance.
AP_PWR_1.recommendations_description: If it is caused by your manual restart or abnormal power supply, you can ignore this message.

recommendations.text: Ensure your router is connected to a stable power source. Avoid using power strips or extension cords if possible.
Ensure all cables are securely connected and there are no visible damages. You shall reduce the number of coaxial splitters to your equipment.
Make sure your router is placed in a well-ventilated area to prevent overheating.

summary.title: What Happened?
summary.description: Your Wi-Fi network named <1>{{networkName}}</1> has detected severe interference. This can cause slow speeds, dropped connections, and poor performance.

recommendations.text: Sometimes, a simple reboot will help router to auto-configure based a new environment. Unplug your router, wait for 5 seconds, and plug it back in.
Place your router in a central location, away from walls, metal objects, and other electronic devices that can cause interference.
Keep devices like microwaves, cordless phones, and baby monitors away from your router as they can cause interference.
For critical applications.

INTF_SET_3.title_head:
Your network is not
protected by a Wi-Fi
password

summary.title: What Happened?
summary.description: The Wi-Fi network named <1>{{networkName}}</1> has its security settings open or disabled. This means that the network is not protected by a password, making it vulnerable to unauthorized access and potential security threats.

INTF_SET_3.conclusion: After saving, reconnect your devices to the Wi-Fi using the new password.
INTF_SET_3.recommendations_description: Improve your network's security and performance by setting up a Wi-Fi password in the app. Here's how:

recommendations.text: Go to <1>"My Wi-Fi"</1> in the app.
Select your Wi-Fi network.
Tap <1>"Security"</1>.
Choose <1>"WPA2"</1> as minimum security type.
Enter your new Wi-Fi password in the text field.
Tap <1>"Save"</1>.
